dt.t: {wi}discerned{/wi} a figure approaching through the fog

dt: {bc}to detect with senses other than vision
{bc}to come to know or recognize mentally

quotes.t: The ability to {qword}discern{/qword} value at a glimpse, to sift the useful out of the rejected with as little expenditure of energy as possible, is the great talent of the scavenger.

Astronomers are delighted to have found 19 galaxies that appear to be bent out of shape. The distorted images are cosmic mirages, arcs or rings of light created when the gravity of a massive foreground object bends and magnifies the light from a galaxy lying behind it. Albert Einstein predicted the effect … in 1936, but telescopes at the time weren't powerful enough to {qword}discern{/qword} it.
Despite the layers of ironic hesitation, the reader soon {qword}discerns{/qword} that the emotions informing the book are raw and, more importantly, authentic.
A careful analysis of the "Nutrition Facts" panels might provide some guidance, but you would have to do a lot of math before you could {qword}discern{/qword} the best choice.

et: Middle English {it}discernen{/it} "to discriminate, perceive rationally, see," borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French {it}discerner,{/it} borrowed from Latin {it}discernere{/it} "to separate, divide off, distinguish," from {it}dis-{/it} {et_link|dis-|dis-} + {it}cernere{/it} "to sift, discern, decide, determine" {ma}{mat|certain:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to detect with senses other than vision
to recognize or identify as separate and distinct : discriminate
